CatDescriptText: Charles Collier Johnson, burner, Schenley Heights and Dorothy Fulton, telephone operator, Hill District were part of the Pittsburgher's Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1960 with question: "Do you think that economic status, race, or religion influences court decisions in civil and criminal cases?" Charles Collier Johnson's answer reads: "I think that, at times, race but not religion or economic status enters into decisions."  Dorothy Fulton's answer reads: "It shouldn't be this way, but it happens.  In such cases, human nature tends to emphasize those things which should not matter."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Charles Collier Johnson wearing light colored button down collared shirt and hat, standing on Liberty Avenue across from the May Building, Downtown;  Portrait of Dorothy Fulton wearing light colored shirt dress and four strand beaded necklace, standing on Liberty Avenue across from Jenkins Arcade, Downtown
